introduction.p: What are the relations between the coordinates and times assigned to the same event in two inertial frames that are in relative motion with respect to each other? In the section in time dilation we saw that duration of time is different in the two frames. How about position and length?

Let frame S^{\prime} be moving relative to frame S towards positive x-axis direction of the S frame with speed V as shown in . At some point in time, origins of the the two frames will be at the same point in space, we will use that instant to set zero of time in both frames.

figure.caption: Time and position coordinates of an event in two frames in relative motion. We will set t = 0 = t' when origins of the the two frames at same point.

subsection.title: Derivation of Lorentz transformations
subsection.p: We want one-to-one relation between events in the two frames. Its important to note that the relation between the two sets of coordinates and times must be linear. If not, then two or more events in one frame may correspond to single event in the other.

Coordinates perpendicular to relative motion of frames: Since relative motion of frames S and S' is along their common x-axis, y and z coordinates in the two systems will be same in the two frames since their origins coincided at t=0=t'.
y = y',\ \ z = z'.

Now, we need relations for (x,t) and (x',t'). Since we expect linear relations, we will work out the unknown coefficients, A, B, C, and D in the following equations.
\amp t = A\:t' + B\: x' \amp x = C\:t' + D\: x'
To find these four coefficients we will apply them to following four events.

Event 1: x=0 at some time t in S. This corresponds to x' = -V t' in S'. Using these values in Eq. , we get
0 = C\:t' - D\: V t'.
Therefore,
C = D\: V.

Event 2: x' = 0 at some t' in S'. This event corresponds to x = Vt for some time t in S. Therefore, Eqs. and give
\amp t = A\:t' \amp Vt = C\:t'
Dividing these two equations we obtain
C = A\: V.
From Eqs. and we find
A = D.
Event 3: Send a light pulse from the origin of the two coordinates when they were at the same location at time t=0=t' towards positive x-axis as shown in .

sidebyside.p: The location of the pulse in the two systems will be x = c t and x' = c t' since light has same speed in the two systems and the pulse will be traveling towards positive x-axis in both systems.

subsection.p:
Putting these values for x and x' in Eqs. and and using A = D and C = D V = A V we get
\amp t = A\:t' + B \: c t' \amp c t = A V\:t' + A\: c t'
By dividing these equations and rearranging you can show that
B = A\:\dfrac{V}{c^2}.
Now, we need to find the expression for A only. The others can be obtained from A.
Event 4: Send a light pulse at t'=0=t from the origin travels towards positive y' axis in the S' frame as shown in .

sidebyside.p: The pulse travels a distance ct' towards positive y' axis in S' but travels at a diagonal a distance of ct in frame S.

subsection.p:
Since the speed of light is same in the two frames, in frame S the path length of light in time t along the diagonal of the triangle will equal c t and along y-axis by amount ct'. From the right-angled triangle in the figure we get
(Vt)^2 + (ct'))^2 = (ct)^2 \ \ \longrightarrow \ \ t'^2 = \left( 1 - \frac{V^2}{c^2} \right)\, t^2.
From above we have
t = A\:t' + B \: x'= A\: t'.
Therefore,
t'^2 = \left( 1 - \frac{V^2}{c^2} \right)\, A^2 t'^2.
Hence,
A = \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} = \pm \gamma.
From our thought experiments presented above, both t and t' are positive, we discard the netative solution and write
A = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} \equiv \gamma.
Now, we can write other coefficients also.
B = \gamma\: V/c^2,\ \ C = \gamma\: V,\ \ D = \gamma.
Using these we have the Lorentz transformation corresponding to the .
\amp t = \gamma\, t' + \gamma\: V/c^2\: x'. \amp x = \gamma\, V t' + \gamma\: x'.

statement.p: Describe the following physical occurrences as events: (a) A postman rings a doorbell of a house precisely at noon, (b) At the same time as the doorbell is rung a slice of bread pops out of a toaster which is located 10 m from the door in the East direction from the door, (c) 10 sec later an airplane arrives at the airport, which is 10 km from the door in the East direction and 2 km to the South.

hint.p: Event is (time, position) or (t, x, y, z) of an occurence.

solution.p: (a) Let origin be at the bell and time t=0 correspond to the noon time. then, we can say that event (t, x, y, z) for this event is (0, 0, 0, 0).
(b) Using x axis from bell to the toaster, we will get (t, x, y, z) = (0, 10\text{ m}, 0, 0).
(c) Supposing y axis is to the North, we will get (t, x, y, z) = (0, 10\text{ km}, -2\text{ m}, 0).

exercise.title: Coordinates and Times Assigned to an Event Described in another Frame

statement.p: A train arrives at a location ( x = x_0, y = 0, z = 0) at time t=10\text{ sec} in a frame S at rest with respect to the train station. A spaceship is passing by with velocity (3,000\text{ m/s},0,0) with respect to train station. What will be the coordinates and time the pilot will assign to the event of the train arrival?

solution.p:
Let us denote Pilot's frame by \text{S}^\prime. Then, this problem corresponds to . Suppose frame S and \text{S}^\prime are coincident with zero reading of time in each frame. Denoting event in \text{S}^\prime by (t', x', y', z') for event (0,0,0,0) in frame S, we have
\amp t' = \dfrac{t - V x/c^2}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} = \dfrac{t}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} \amp x' = \dfrac{x - Vt}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} = \dfrac{- Vt}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}}
Since relative motion is only along common x-axis, no change will occur in y and z coordinates. To compute numrical value, we first compute \gamma.
\gamma = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1 -10^{-10}}} \approx 1 + \frac{1}{2}\times 10^{-10}.
Therefore,
\amp t' = \left( 1 + \frac{1}{2}\times 10^{-10} \right) \times 10\text{ sec}. \amp x' = -\left( 1 + \frac{1}{2}\times 10^{-10} \right) \times 3\times 10^{4}\text{ m}.

exercise.title: Same Events Described by Observers in Two Frames

statement.p: In frame S two events are observed: event 1 - a pion is created at rest at the origin and event 2- the pion disintegrates after time \tau, also at origin. Another observer in another frame S' is moving towards positive x-axis of S frame with a constant speed V wathces the same two events in his frame. The origin of the two frames coincide at zero time in both frames. (a) Find the positions and timings of these two events in the frame S' and (b) describe how the observer in S' will describe these two events.

solution.p:
By using formulas of Lorentz transformation, we can immediately write values for the event in S'. For event 1 we get
\amp t'_1 = \dfrac{t}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} = 0 \amp x'_1 = \dfrac{- Vt}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} = 0
and for event 2 we get
\amp t'_2 = \dfrac{\tau}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}} \amp x'_2 = \dfrac{- V\tau}{\sqrt{1 - V^2/c^2}}.
